dt: {bc}one of the often indefinite or unequal subdivisions into which something is or is regarded as divided and which together constitute the whole

dt.t: … the road was passable only {wi}part{/wi} of the year …
Change is an inevitable {wi}part{/wi} of life.

dt: {bc}one of several or many equal units of which something is composed or into which it is divisible {bc}an amount equal to another amount

dt.t: mix one {wi}part{/wi} of the powder with three {wi}parts{/wi} of water

dt: {bc}one of the constituent elements of a plant or animal body: such as

dt.t: The stomach is {wi}part{/wi} of the digestive system.

dt: {bc}a vocal or instrumental line or melody in concerted music or in harmony
{bc}a {a_link|particular} voice or instrument in concerted music
{bc}a constituent member of a machine or other apparatus
{bc}something falling to one in a division or apportionment {bc}{sx|share||}
{bc}one's share or allotted task (as in an action) {bc}{sx|duty||}
{bc}one of the opposing sides in a conflict or dispute

dt.t: he that is not against us is on our {wi}part{/wi}

dt: {bc}a function or course of action performed

dt.t: objected to the government's {wi}part{/wi} in the strike

dt: {bc}an actor's lines in a play, movie, etc.
{bc}the role of a character in a play, movie, etc.

dt.t: His {wi}part{/wi} was on the left side of his head.

dt: {bc}as far as one's share or interest is concerned

dt.t: {it}for my part{/it}, I do not see that the difference is important
{it}for the most part{/it} the crowd was orderly

pt: {sc}part{/sc} {sc}portion{/sc} {sc}piece{/sc} {sc}member{/sc} {sc}division{/sc} {sc}section{/sc} {sc}segment{/sc} {sc}fragment{/sc} mean something less than the whole. {sc}part{/sc} is a general term appropriate when indefiniteness is required.

pt.t: they ran only {it}part{/it} of the way

pt: {sc}portion{/sc} implies an assigned or allotted part.
{sc}piece{/sc} applies to a separate or detached part of a whole.
{sc}member{/sc} suggests one of the functional units composing a body.
{sc}division{/sc} applies to a large or diversified part.
{sc}section{/sc} applies to a relatively small or uniform part.
{sc}segment{/sc} applies to a part separated or marked out by or as if by natural lines of cleavage.
{sc}fragment{/sc} applies to a part produced by or as if by breaking off.

pt.t: only a {it}fragment{/it} of the play still exists

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French & Old English, both from Latin {it}part-, pars{/it}; perhaps akin to Latin {it}parare{/it} to prepare {ma}{mat|pare|}{/ma}
shortdef: one of the often indefinite or unequal subdivisions into which something is or is regarded as divided and which together constitute the whole
an essential portion or integral element
one of several or many equal units of which something is composed or into which it is divisible : an amount equal to another amount

dt: {bc}to separate from or take leave of someone
{bc}to separate by combing on each side of a line
{bc}to break or suffer the breaking of (something, such as a rope or anchor chain)

dt.t: if aught but death {wi}part{/wi} thee and me
the narrow channel that {wi}parts{/wi} England from France

dt: {bc}to separate by a process of extraction, elimination, or secretion

pt: {sc}separate{/sc} {sc}part{/sc} {sc}divide{/sc} {sc}sever{/sc} {sc}sunder{/sc} {sc}divorce{/sc} mean to become or cause to become disunited or disjointed. {sc}separate{/sc} may imply any of several causes such as dispersion, removal of one from others, or presence of an intervening thing.

pt.t: {it}separated{/it} her personal life from her career

pt: {sc}part{/sc} implies the separating of things or persons in close union or association.
{sc}divide{/sc} implies separating into pieces or sections by cutting or breaking.
{sc}sever{/sc} implies violence especially in the removal of a part or member.
{sc}sunder{/sc} suggests violent rending or wrenching apart.
{sc}divorce{/sc} implies separating two things that commonly interact and belong together.

pt.t: cannot {it}divorce{/it} scientific research from moral responsibility

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}partir{/it}, from Latin {it}partire{/it} to divide, from {it}part-, pars{/it}
shortdef: to separate from or take leave of someone
to take leave of one another

dt: {bc}a series of verb forms from which all the other forms of a verb can be derived including in English the infinitive, the past tense, and the present and past participles

shortdef: a series of verb forms from which all the other forms of a verb can be derived including in English the infinitive, the past tense, and the present and past participles
the external genital and excretory organs

dt: {bc}fractional parts of the difference between successive entries in a table for use in linear interpolation

shortdef: fractional parts of the difference between successive entries in a table for use in linear interpolation

meta.id: greater/better/more than the sum of its parts
stems: better than the sum of its parts
greater than the sum of its parts
greater/better/more than the sum of its parts
more than the sum of its parts

hwi.hw: greater/better/more than the sum of its parts

dt: used to say that something is better or more effective as a team, combination, etc., than would be expected when looking at the different parts that form it

dt.t: The team lacks standout players, but it has proved to be {it}greater than the sum of its parts{/it}.

shortdef: —used to say that something is better or more effective as a team, combination, etc., than would be expected when looking at the different parts that form it
